title: Health Consequences of Processed Food
content: The health consequences of processed food with a focus on the gut microbiome. Processed food can lead to inflammation from gut permeability. There are steps to fixing a bad gut, known as the Five R’s.

title: Health Statistics and Genetic Susceptibility
content: There are some staggering health statistics, and certain races might be more genetically susceptible to health issues related to diet.

title: Industrial Farming and Health
content: Industrial farming and the use of fertilizers can have negative impacts on health. The potential health risks of consuming GMO foods sprayed with Roundup (glyphosate) and other herbicides and pesticides are discussed.

title: Regenerative Agriculture and Health
content: Regenerative agriculture could be the answer to food waste, our health problems, and the environment. The comparison of the “Impossible Burger” to regeneratively raised beef is discussed.

title: Loss of Biodiversity in Food
content: The loss of biodiversity in our food, and what “organic” really means. The livelihood of farmers are being affected by big ag companies and the current industrial farming system.

title: Individual Actions for Healthier Food System
content: What can people do on the individual level to protect themselves as well as affect change to the toxic food system? The role of the USDA in this “toxic” food environment and how to fix it is discussed.

title: Bread in the US vs. Europe
content: Why does bread (and wheat products) taste different and potentially cause less health problems in Europe versus the US?

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. Relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer. New focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding.

title: Impact of stress on physical and emotional health
content: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health.

title: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies
content: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Training principles for longevity.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease
content: Preventing cardiovascular disease: the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Negative consequences of the existing food environment
content: The majority of patients are sick due to some relationship to food. The food system we have is the problem. It's because of the food policies. There's 11 million people that die every year from eating ultra processed food and not enough of the good food.

title: The main pillars making the current food environment toxic
content: Food is the biggest driver of chronic disease affecting six out of 10 people. It’s clearly the biggest driver of economic stress in this country, in our $22 trillion debt. It’s also driving climate change. It’s causing massive environmental degradation including loss of bio-diversity. It’s driving social injustice in many ways through how it affects our kids’ cognitive development and ability to learn. It leads to massive health disparities because poor communities are more affected by these foods and are more targeted by them. It even threatens our national security because 70% of military recruits are unfit to fight and they are rejected.

title: What makes processed food so unhealthy?
content: Our diet has changed so radically, not just in the last 10,000 years, but in the last 40 years with the advent of massive amounts of ultra processed food and that’s driving cognitive behavioral issues, violence, suicide, conflict, etc.

title: Power of Food in Health
content: Food has the power to cause disease and the power to cure disease. There is a lack of understanding about this. Processed foods are particularly difficult metabolically for our species. Historically, humans ate around 800 different species of plants and consumed almost 100 g of fiber per day. Now, the average is about 8 grams of fiber per day. The development of industrial agriculture created an abundance of calories that solved hunger issues around the world, but the unintended consequence was the obesity epidemic. Our biology isn’t adapted to eating highly refined foods, yet it’s about 60% of our calories. Every 10% of your calories that’s ultra processed food, your risk of death goes up by 14%.

title: Effects of Processed Foods
content: Processed foods contain refined soybean oil, food additives, chemicals, BPA from plastics, other metabolic toxins, and pesticides and glyphosate affecting our microbiome. Refined starches and sugars affect your biology. They raise insulin, which has a cascading effect of fat storage in your belly, which is a dangerous fat. It leads to increased hunger, affects your brain chemistry, locks the fat in the fat cells so that can’t get out, and slows your metabolism. There’s different effects of food on your biology, independent of calories. 750 calories of Coke is NOT the same as 750 calories of broccoli, for example, they have profoundly different effects on your biology.

title: Inflammation from Processed Food and Sugars
content: Processed food and sugars can cause inflammation. There is a lot of genetic variability from person to person in terms of their tolerance. But anyone will do better when eating a whole foods, unprocessed diet. You can actually measure inflammation in response to diet through various biomarkers through CRP or SED rate. Insulin is another inflammation driving hormone. Processed foods drive up insulin which leads to visceral belly fat. This starts a 'metabolic fire' in these cells and it spreads inflammation throughout the body.

title: Gut Microbiome and Health
content: The gut microbiome has a huge role in regulation of weight (independent of calories). Your microbiome is regulated by what you eat. The amount of (or lack thereof) fiber, prebiotics, the phytonutrients, phytochemicals, the polyphenols all affect the quality of the 'garden' you have growing inside of you. Our low fiber, high sugar, high processed food diets increase bad bugs in the gut. Antibiotics, acid blockers, antiinflammatory drugs, hormones all screw up our gut as well. And environmental toxins, such as glyphosate, is super toxic to the microbiome.

title: Steps to Fixing a Bad Gut
content: Steps to fixing a bad gut include: Remove foods that may be triggering a problem like gluten, dairy, grains for some people and 'bad bugs'. Replace what might be missing like fiber, prebiotics, enzymes. Reinoculate with probiotics where necessary. Repair the body with certain nutrients to heal like glutamine, vitamin A, fish oil, butyrate, polyphenols from food. Restore your nervous system.

title: Health Statistics and Genetic Susceptibility
content: 6 out of 10 Americans have a chronic disease, 4 out of 10 have two or more chronic diseases. In 10 years, 83 million Americans will have 3 or more. 1 in 2 Americans has prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. 75% of us are overweight. Most states now have 40% obesity rates. Genetically, there’s certain segments of the population that are more susceptible to getting obesity and diabetes when they’re in an abundance of sugar and flour. That includes Native Americans, African Americans, Latinos, South Pacific islanders, People from India, China, and Asians people often are at much higher risk even at lower body rates.

title: Government Regulations and Policies
content: Government regulations and policies can help fight back against a massive food industry with unlimited resources. Chile, for example, is attempting to address the massive obesity rates in kids and adults and the staggering healthcare cost by taxing soda, putting warning labels on bad food, eliminating any processed foods from school lunches, eliminating any advertising on junk food from 6am until 10pm. The restriction of food marketing and the warning label had a fourfold increased benefit compared to the soda tax.

title: Health Risks of Soda Consumption
content: Consuming soda can lead to obesity, diabetes, cancer, dementia, and early death.

title: Food Industry Tactics
content: The food industry is using tactics similar to the tobacco industry to slow or stall regulations. For example, the American Beverage Association put in a ballot measure in California designed to prohibit local taxes unless it was a two-thirds majority. This would hamper local governments dramatically. They also pushed for a preemptive law that prohibits any future taxes on soda or junk food.

title: Misinformation about Calories
content: An initiative called the Global Energy Balance Network (GEBN) promoted the idea that all calories are the same and it was simply about moderation and calories in/calories out. This is misinformation as not all calories have the same nutritional value.

title: Industrial Farming and Climate Change
content: Industrial farming contributes to climate change through deforestation and soil destruction. The industrial growing of food tills the soil and disrupts the normal organic matter, causing soil erosion which releases carbon into the environment. Soil is one of the biggest solutions to fixing climate change as it can hold three times the amount of carbon that’s in the atmosphere today.

title: Fertilizer and Soil Destruction
content: Fertilizer is driving the destruction of our soil. There’s 400 billion pounds of fertilizer used everywhere in the world. It’s a seven-fold increase over the last 40 years because they are only two-thirds as effective as they used to be. The process of making fertilizer is chemically intensive and uses energy, contributing to climate change.

title: Regenerative Agriculture
content: Regenerative agriculture could be the answer to food waste, our health problems, and the environment. It increases production and interrupts problems that are driving climate change. For example, it reduces the need for factory-made fertilizer which damages the soil and releases nitrous oxide, a potent greenhouse gas.

title: Effects of Fertilizer on Soil Health
content: In order to get dirt to produce plants, you need to put on more and more amounts of fertilizer. Fertilizer is seven fold compared to 40 years ago. It allows us to be lazy and rely less on healthy soil because you can dump fertilizer on dirt and eventually grow what you need. But if you actually want the healthiest soil possible, you will need to get your nitrogen contribution from an element that stays within the ecosystem of the soil because it’s a part of it and therefore you’re not going to have the runoff.

title: Food Waste and Climate Change
content: The UN estimates that humans waste 30-40% of our food. We waste food in the developed world via we throw out food in our kitchen. We lose food in the food chain because of lack of storage and transportation, refrigeration. All these food production processes add up to about 50% of climate change.

title: Regenerative Agriculture and Climate Change
content: Regenerative agriculture techniques could be easily applied and are done in literally millions of acres around the world with great benefit and high productivity and mitigating climate at the same time. It’s been estimated by some that we could draw down anywhere from 30 to a 100% of all the carbon that’s been released since the industrial revolution, if we can scale this up.

title: Health Risks of GMO Foods and Glyphosate
content: Many crops, corn for example, can be genetically modified so that they are resistant to the effects of glyphosate (Roundup) which is an herbicide (weed-killer). That way, the plants will survive getting sprayed but the weeds will die. It MIGHT be harmful to be eating an organism that now has a gene that looks different from the gene that we evolved to consume it. In other words, it now makes different proteins that it didn’t make that are foreign. It enables the use of chemicals (e.g., RoundUp/glyphosate) in a higher concentration than you would be able to use them in the absence of genetic modifications to the plant. In other words, the food is getting exposed to Roundup (glyphosate) and it may be harmful for people to be consuming that.

title: Industrial Agriculture and Health Risks
content: If it was the only way to grow food, fine, we deal with the risks. It’s not, it’s not the best way. It’s not the most effective way and there is potential risk and there’s real concern about our industrial agricultural system on the earth.

title: Loss of Biodiversity and Health
content: We’ve lost 90% of our edible plant species. Basically 60% of our calories comes from corn and wheat and rice and soy and mostly from 12 species. We’ve lost half our livestock species. We have lost 75% of our pollinator species (e.g., bees) on which are agriculture depends.

title: Chemicals and Soil Health
content: The chemicals that we use in the soil and the farming methods we use is destroying the soil which is an incredible diverse ecosystem: mycorrhizal fungi, the bacteria, the nematodes, the worms, all these different animals that live in the soil that are necessary to actually create food and to create sustainable agriculture.

title: Organic Food and Health
content: Organic is a certification that’s delivered by the government which means no antibiotics, no pesticides, no herbicides. However, it doesn’t certify the method of growing the food. Regenerative is the method of farming that actually includes organic but goes beyond it.

title: Individual Actions for Healthier Food System
content: Things people can do: Being really focused on what you eat and where it comes from. Buy from a local farmer’s market. Joining a community support that supports agriculture. Looking for regenerative sources online. Bulk buying things together with friends. Maybe you should have a compost pile.

title: Food Waste and Health
content: Food waste is an incredible problem. 30 or 40% of all food producers wasted. The average family throws out about a pound a day or about $1,800 a year of food. This much food in a landfill would create greenhouse gases that would be the third largest emitter of greenhouse gases (after the US and China).

title: USDA and Toxic Food Environment
content: At the high level, the USDA is responsible for a number of different food and ag policies that are “messed up”. Our dietary guidelines. Our school lunch guidelines. SNAP program (aka Food stamp program). Then you have crop insurance and agricultural supports that support harmful a industrial agricultural system.

title: FDA and Food Safety
content: The FDA that has confusing food labels or that allows antibiotics in our animal feed. It allows substances that are banned in other countries that are toxic to be in our food supply.

title: Regenerative Agriculture and Health
content: Without animals integrated into regenerative agricultural systems, you cannot restore soil in the way we need to restore it as fast as we need to restore it. Pooping, peeing, digging, and even their saliva makes the plants grow. With proper management (aka holistic management, or managed grazing, or adaptive multi-paddock grazing)… “you can dramatically increase soil”.

title: Role of Animals in Environmental Health
content: Whether or not you believe in eating meat, from an environmental or a climate standpoint, we must have animals integrated into the process in order to restore soil, which is the biggest carbon sink.

title: Photosynthesis and Climate Change
content: There are a lot of ways to fix climate change, but the quickest, fastest, and most effective and scalable way is using an ancient carbon capture technology . . . is free. It’s called photosynthesis. It’s basically sun and carbon dioxide in the air. We can solve a lot of the global issues that we have.

title: Differences in Wheat Products Between US and Europe
content: In the US, we’ve hybridized the wheat to make it extremely drought resistant and hardy and it’s called dwarf wheat. However, there is a “super starch” in there called amylopectin A that raises your blood sugar more than regular sugar. There’s extra proteins that are formed such as gliadin proteins which are inflammatory and more active in terms of causing disruptions in the gut. In the US, we spray wheat with glyphosate at harvest. This is a preservative which is added to the wheat in US. It’s known to cause toxic neurological effects, behavioral hyperactivity, and has been linked to autism. In the US, our breads rise in a couple hours. In Europe, it can take 12 hours to 14 hours. It tastes very different and it’s a very different structure. It does different things to the gluten. There’s no GMO in Europe.

title: Alternative Wheat Options
content: Better wheats include: Heirloom wheats, Einkorn wheat. There’s a new forms of wheat being developed: One is Kernza grain by The Land Institute. It has incredibly deep roots, it’s a perennial wheat, it’s super nutrient dense. Another is Himalayan buckwheat. Apparently it is one of the most protein rich, low-glycemic, phytochemical dense hardy super foods on the planet.
